facts.text: Civil Appeal No.130 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.130 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate granted by the Madras High Court against its judgment and order dated November 1, 1957, in W. Nos. 623 and 624 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate granted by the Madras High Court against its judgment and order dated November 1, 1957, in W. Nos. 623 and 624 of 1957.

facts.text: In the 1957 general elections, nine persons filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Sathankulam constituency all of which were found on scrutiny to be valid.

anchor.surface_text: In the 1957 general elections, nine persons filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Sathankulam constituency all of which were found on scrutiny to be valid.

facts.text: Candidates included the appellant, the respondent Kandaswami, R. Meganathan and G. E. Muthu.

anchor.surface_text: Among these persons were the appellant, the respondent Kandaswami and two others called R. Meganathan and G. E. Muthu.

facts.text: Meganathan, Muthu and three others dropped out of the election earlier and did not go to the poll.

anchor.surface_text: Meganathan, Muthu and three others whom it is not necessary to name as they are not concerned with this appeal, did not go to the poll and dropped out of the election earlier.

facts.text: The election was contested by the appellant, the respondent Kandaswami and two other candidates.

anchor.surface_text: At the end the election was actually contested by the appellant, the respondent Kandaswami and two other candidates with whom also this appeal is not concerned.

facts.text: The appellant was successful at the poll and was declared elected on March 6, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was successful at the poll and was on March 6,1957, declared elected.

facts.text: On April 15, 1957, the respondent Kandaswami preferred an election petition under the Representation of the People Act, 1951, for declaration that the election of the appellant was void.

anchor.surface_text: On April 15, 1957, the respondent Kandaswami whom we will hereafter refer to as the respondent, preferred an election petition under the provisions of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, for a declaration that the election of the appellant was void.

facts.text: The appellant was made the first respondent to the election petition but Meganathan and Muthu were not made parties to it.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was made the first respondent to the petition but Meganathan and Muthu were not made parties to it at all.

facts.text: The petition was referred to an Election Tribunal for trial.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was referred to an Election Tribunal for trial.

facts.text: The appellant made an application I.A. No. 1 of 1957 to the Election Tribunal for dismissal of the petition under s.90(3) for non-compliance with s.82.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then made an application to the Election Tribunal which was marked I. A. No. 1 of 1957 for the dismissal of the petition under s. 90(3) of the Act.

facts.text: The Tribunal dismissed the appellant's application, accepting the respondent's contention that no allegation of corrupt practice against Meganathan or Muthu.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accepted the contention of the respondent and dismissed the application of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant moved Madras High Court with two applications for writ of certiorari and prohibition, dismissed on November 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court at Madras by two applications... The High Court by its judgment dated November 1, 1957, dismissed both the applications.

facts.text: Meganathan and Muthu were candidates as defined in s.79 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that Meganathan and Muthu were candidates. A candidate has been defined in s. 79 of the Act...

facts.text: Election petition alleged that first respondent (appellant) and his election agent paid Rs.10,000 gift to Sri M.R. Meganathan to induce withdrawal from Sathankulam, and he withdrew.

anchor.surface_text: Sri M. R. Meganathan was candidate... The first respondent and his election Agent paid him a gift of Rs. 10,000 to induce him to withdraw... and in pursuance thereof Sri M. R. Meganathan withdrew his candidature...

facts.text: Election petition alleged that first respondent and election agent paid Rs.5,000 gratification to Sri G.E. Muthu to retire from contest, and he retired.

anchor.surface_text: One Sri G. E. Muthu, candidate... was paid a gratification of Rs. 5,000 by the first respondent and his Election Agent... and in pursuance thereof he retired from the contest.

facts.text: Appellant contended that allegations of corrupt practice were made against Meganathan and Muthu, requiring them as parties under s.82(b).

anchor.surface_text: The petition is liable to be dismissed for non-joinder of Muthu and Meganathan who were candidates... The allegation is that Meganathan accepted a gift...

facts.text: Respondent contended that acceptance of gift is not a corrupt practice under s.123(1), so Meganathan and Muthu not necessary parties.

anchor.surface_text: A candidate who accepts a gift from a returned candidate does not commit corrupt practice within the meaning of s. 123(1) and therefore is not necessary party...

facts.text: High Court held that only giving of bribe is corrupt practice, not acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that it was not and that only the giving of a bribe was a corrupt practice and not an acceptance of it.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court that allegation of acceptance is not allegation of corrupt practice against the acceptor.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with this view.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SARKAR J. on May 20, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. May 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.

facts.text: Non-compliance with s.82 entails dismissal of election petition, not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that non-compliance with the provisions of s. 82 entails the dismissal of an election petition.

facts.text: Meganathan was candidate for Sathankulam and Tiruchendur Assembly Constituencies.

anchor.surface_text: Sri M. R. Meganathan was candidate for Sattankulam and Tiruchandur Assembly Constituencies at the election.

facts.text: Hearing dates: April 30, May 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. April 30. May 1.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, T. R. Venkatarama Iyer, K. R. Sharma and K. R. Choudhri.

anchor.surface_text: A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, T. R. Venkatarama Iyer, K. R. Sharma and K. R. Choudhri, for the appellant.

The petition is liable to be dismissed for non- joinder of Muthu and Meganathan who were candidates as defined in s. 79 b  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951. The allegation is that Meganathan accepted a gift of Rs. 10,000 and in pursuance thereof withdrew his candidature, and also that Muthu accepted a gratification of Rs. 5,000 and in pursuance thereof, he retired from the companytest. On the language of s. 123 1  of the Act, such acceptance companystitutes a companyrupt practice. See ss. 82  b , 98 and 99 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

concepts.interpretation: A petitioner shall join as respondents to his petition any other candidate against whom allegations of any corrupt practice are made in the petition. Non-compliance leads to dismissal under s.90(3).

anchor.surface_text: IV-A. The returned candidate has companymitted the following act, of bribery-corrupt practices according to section 123 1  of Act 43 of 1951 - Sri M. R. Meganathan was candidate for Sattankulam and Tiruchandur Assembly Constituencies at the election. The first respondent and his election Agent paid him a gift of Rs. 10,000 to induce him to withdraw from being a candidate at the election from Sattankulam Constituency and in pursuance thereof Sri M. R. Meganathan withdrew his candidature at the election from Sattankulam Constituency, One Sri G. E. Muthu, candidate at the election in this Constituency was paid a gratification of Rs. 5,000 by the first respondent and his Election Agent for the purpose of making him retire from companytest and in pursuance thereof he retired on the companytest Section 123-The following shall be deemed to be companyrupt practices for the purposes of this Act Bribery, that is to say, any gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person, of any gratification to any person whomsoever, with the object directly or indirectly of inducing  a  a person to stand or number to stand as, or to withdraw from being, a candidate, or to retire from companytest, at an election

concepts.interpretation: Bribery as corrupt practice is the gift, offer or promise by a candidate/agent/other with object of inducing withdrawal etc.; does not include acceptance of such gift/gratification.

issues.text: whether allegations of corrupt practice are made against Meganathan and Muthu in the election petition

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises in this appeal is whether allegations of corrupt practice are made against them in the election petition. The statements in- the petition which are said to constitute such allegations are in these terms

issues.text: Is an allegation that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election contest and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate?

anchor.surface_text: Putting it shortly, the allegations in the petition are that the appellant and his election agent paid Meganathan Rs. 10,000 and Muthu Rs. 5,000 to induce them to drop out of the election and they accordingly abandoned the election contest. So all that is said here against Meganathan and Muthu and we are concerned only with allegations against them- is that they accepted money paid to them to induce them to abandon the contest and actually abandoned the contest. Is an allegation then,

issues.text: is an acceptance of a bribe a corrupt practice within the definition of section 123?

anchor.surface_text: is an acceptance of a bribe, by which word we mean a gift made with the intention specified, a corrupt practice within this definition ? We do not think it is. What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person,

issues.text: does section 123(1) contemplate the acceptance of a gift to be a corrupt practice, considering the deletion of section 124(3)?

anchor.surface_text: That s. 123 1  does not contemplate the acceptance of a gift to be a corrupt practice is also apparent from a consideration of s. 124 of the Act which was deleted by an amendment made by Act XXVII of 1956. Under el.  3  of that section the receipt of or an agreement to receive a gift with substantially the same object as mentioned in s. 123 was a corrupt practice.

issues.text: in view of the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act, there can be no gift without an acceptance of it by the donee, and therefore does mention of gift in section 123(1) include acceptance?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri then contended that in view of the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act, there can be no gift without an acceptance of it by the donee, and therefore whenever a gift is mentioned both the giving and the acceptance of the thing given are necessarily simultaneously contemplated.

issues.text: does section 99 show that the receipt of a bribe is a corrupt practice, requiring naming of consenting candidates?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri also contended that s. 99 of the Act showed that the receipt of a bribe was a corrupt practice. Section 98 states that at the conclusion of the trial of an election petition the Tribunal shall make one or other of the orders therein mentioned. Then comes s. 99 which states that in certain circumstances besides these orders,

issues.text: is the term gratification in s.123 very wide and include the withdrawal of candidature by a candidate to induce another candidate to stand?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri then said that the term gratification in s. 123 was very wide and would include the withdrawal of his candidature by a candidate to induce another candidate to stand at an election. He contended that the affording of such a gratification would amount to a corrupt practice within s. 123.

issues.text: does section 82(b) talk of allegations of any corrupt practice and therefore contemplate any allegation relating to or concerning a corrupt practice?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, Mr. Sastri contended that s. 82 b  talked of allegations of any corrupt practice and it therefore contemplated any allegation relating to or concerning, a corrupt practice. He said that the election petition contained allegations against Meganathan and Muthu, relating to a corrupt practice inasmuch as it stated that they accepted the gratifications paid to them

anchor.surface_text: The petition is liable to be dismissed for non- joinder of Muthu and Meganathan who were candidates as defined in s. 79 b  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951. The allegation is that Meganathan accepted a gift of Rs. 10,000 and in pursuance thereof withdrew his candidature, and also that Muthu accepted a gratification of Rs. 5,000 and in pursuance thereof, he retired from the companytest.

arguments.court_reasoning: No allegations of corrupt practice against them; acceptance not a corrupt practice under s.123.

arguments.claim: On the language of s.123(1) of the Act, acceptance of gift or gratification constitutes a corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: On the language of s. 123 1  of the Act, such acceptance constitutes a corrupt practice.

arguments.claim: Allegations do not constitute corrupt practice against Meganathan/Muthu; only question in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises in this appeal is whether allegations of corrupt practice are made against them in the election petition.

arguments.claim: s.123(1) makes corrupt practice the gift/offer/promise by candidate/agent/other, not acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person, of any gratification made with the object mentioned.

arguments.claim: Deletion of s.124(3) indicates acceptance not included in s.123(1) as CP.

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act has dropped the provision making acceptance and an agreement to accept a bribe, a corrupt practice but has made no change in s. 123 1  to bring within it these cases.

arguments.claim: s.82(b) requires joining candidate only if allegation that he committed CP.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that when s. 82 b  talks of allegations of corrupt practice against a candidate it means allegations that a candidate has committed a corrupt practice.

holdings.text: Allegations that Meganathan and Muthu accepted money to withdraw from the election do not constitute allegations of corrupt practice against them.

anchor.surface_text: Putting it shortly, the allegations in the petition are that the appellant and his election agent paid Meganathan Rs. 10,000 and Muthu Rs. 5,000 to induce them to drop out of the election and they accordingly abandoned the election contest. So all that is said here against Meganathan and Muthu...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petition alleges payment by appellant to induce withdrawal; acceptance not alleged as corrupt practice under s.123.

holdings.text: Acceptance of a bribe is not a corrupt practice within the definition of section 123(1).

anchor.surface_text: is an acceptance of a bribe, by which word we mean a gift made with the intention specified, a corrupt practice within this definition ? We do not think it is. What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.123(1) defines bribery as gift/offer/promise by candidate/agent/other with inducing object; words inappropriate for acceptance.

holdings.text: Section 123(1) contemplates only the making (giving) of a gift as corrupt practice, not its acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person, of any gratification made with the object mentioned. The words gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person clearly show that what is contemplated is the making of a gift.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.123(1) focuses on act of giving with specified object; acceptance not mentioned.

holdings.text: Deletion of s.124(3) by 1956 amendment indicates legislative intent that acceptance of bribe is no longer a corrupt practice under s.123(1).

anchor.surface_text: That s. 123(1) does not contemplate the acceptance of a gift to be a corrupt practice is also apparent from a consideration of s. 124 of the Act which was deleted by an amendment made by Act XXVII of 1956. Under cl.(3) of that section the receipt of or an agreement to receive a gift...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior s.124(3) separately penalized acceptance as minor CP; deletion without amending s.123(1) shows intent to exclude.

holdings.text: Mention of 'gift' in s.123(1) does not include acceptance merely because Transfer of Property Act requires acceptance for valid gift.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that a gift contemplates both a giving and an acceptance but these are nevertheless different acts and it is open to the legislature to attach certain consequences to one of them only. It was therefore open to the legislature in enacting s. 123(1) to provide that the making...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gift involves two acts; legislature penalized only giving, deliberately omitting acceptance.

holdings.text: Consent by a candidate to the commission of a corrupt practice is not itself a corrupt practice under s.123.

anchor.surface_text: Section 99 does not purport to define a corrupt practice. The definition of corrupt practice occurs in s. 123 and the corrupt practice mentioned in s. 99 has to be a corrupt practice as so defined. A corrupt practice committed with the consent of a candidate is not in itself a new kind of corrupt practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.99 refers to CP as defined in s.123; consent not a defined CP.

holdings.text: Withdrawal of candidature by a candidate to induce another to stand is not 'gratification' under s.123.

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable to agree that the withdrawal of his candidature by a candidate to induce another candidate to stand at an election would be gratification within s. 123. But assume it is so. That does not help the appellant at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Term 'gratification' does not encompass non-pecuniary withdrawal; no such allegation anyway.

holdings.text: s.82(b) requires joinder only of candidates against whom it is alleged that they committed a corrupt practice, not mere allegations relating to or concerning a corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that when s. 82(b) talks of allegations of corrupt practice against a candidate it means allegations that a candidate has committed a corrupt practice. Allegations can hardly be said to be against one unless they impute some default to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'allegations of any corrupt practice against a candidate' means imputing commission of CP to that candidate.

anchor.surface_text: Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.

outcome.relief_summary: Held: No allegation of corrupt practice against Meganathan and Muthu as acceptance of gratification is not a corrupt practice under s.123(1); they need not be joined as parties under s.82(b); election petition not liable to dismissal under s.90(3)

anchor.surface_text: as respondents to his petition-  b  any other candidate against whom allegations of any companyrupt

anchor.surface_text: Putting it shortly, the allegations in the petition are that the appellant and his election agent paid Meganathan Rs. 10,000 and Muthu Rs. 5,000 to induce them to drop out of the election and they accordingly abandoned the election contest. So all that is said here against Meganathan and Muthu...

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.

is an acceptance of a bribe, by which word we mean a gift made with the intention specified, a corrupt practice within this definition ? We do not think it is. What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person,

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.

What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person, of any gratification made with the object mentioned. The words gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person clearly show that what is contemplated is the making of a gift.

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.

That s. 123(1) does not contemplate the acceptance of a gift to be a corrupt practice is also apparent from a consideration of s. 124 of the Act which was deleted by an amendment made by Act XXVII of 1956. Under cl.(3) of that section the receipt of or an agreement to receive a gift...

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.
e of them only. It was therefore open to the legislature in enacting s. 123 1  to provide that the making, that is to say, the giving of a gift alone

anchor.surface_text: It is true that a gift contemplates both a giving and an acceptance but these are nevertheless different acts and it is open to the legislature to attach certain consequences to one of them only. It was therefore open to the legislature in enacting s. 123(1) to provide that the making...

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.
ith the companysent of any candidate. He said that when a candidate accepts a gift made to him with the object of inducing him to withdraw his candida

edges.explanation: The holding directly answers the issue by clarifying that consent to a corrupt practice is not itself a corrupt practice under s.123, in the context of the question about s.99 and naming.

anchor.surface_text: Section 99 does not purport to define a corrupt practice. The definition of corrupt practice occurs in s. 123 and the corrupt practice mentioned in s. 99 has to be a corrupt practice as so defined. A corrupt practice committed with the consent of a candidate is not in itself a new kind of corrupt practice.

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.

We are wholly unable to agree that the withdrawal of his candidature by a candidate to induce another candidate to stand at an election would be gratification within s. 123. But assume it is so. That does not help the appellant at all.

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.

We are of opinion that when s. 82(b) talks of allegations of corrupt practice against a candidate it means allegations that a candidate has committed a corrupt practice. Allegations can hardly be said to be against one unless they impute some default to him.

Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election test and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate ? The High Court field that it was number and that only the giving of a bribe was a companyrupt practice and number an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view.
